title: Mercenary
data:
A user has suggested this page be **merged** with *"Yendorian army"*

A **mercenary** is any monster identified by the `is_mercenary()` macro and ultimately defined by the `M2_MERC` flag:

- @ [soldier](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier")
- @ [sergeant](/wiki/Sergeant "Sergeant")
- @ [lieutenant](/wiki/Lieutenant "Lieutenant")
- @ [captain](/wiki/Captain "Captain")
- @ [guard](/wiki/Guard "Guard")
- @ [watchman](/wiki/Watchman "Watchman")
- @ [watch captain](/wiki/Watch_captain "Watch captain")

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Common traits](#Common_traits)

  - [1.1 Starting inventory](#Starting_inventory)
  - [1.2 Weapons](#Weapons)
  - [1.3 Armor](#Armor)
  - [1.4 Other equipment](#Other_equipment)

- [2 Bribery](#Bribery)

- [3 Messages](#Messages)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [4.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [4.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [5 References](#References)

## Common traits

Mercenaries are [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)") and considered part of the [Yendorian Army](/wiki/Yendorian_Army "Yendorian Army"); they have special rules for generating their [starting weapons and armor](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory"), and are among some of the relatively few monsters that can be [bribed](/wiki/Bribe "Bribe"). All mercenaries are [chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic"), and are not valid [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") forms.

As fighters, they only have one weapon attack and lack [monster magic resistance](/wiki/Monster_magic_resistance "Monster magic resistance"), though the higher-ranked mercenaries have a slightly higher resistance stat and are capable of two weapon attacks per turn. Mercenaries will [follow](/wiki/Follow "Follow") the player to other levels, even if they are currently peaceful; like all humans, they do not respect [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth").

### Starting inventory

Mercenaries start with weaponry varying from [short swords](/wiki/Short_sword "Short sword") to [silver sabers](/wiki/Silver_saber "Silver saber"), and armor varying from [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor") to [crystal plate mail](/wiki/Crystal_plate_mail "Crystal plate mail"); most can also be generated with [gloves](/wiki/Gloves "Gloves"), [boots](/wiki/Boots "Boots"), [helmets](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet"), [shields](/wiki/Shield "Shield"), and [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand"). In addition, Yendorian army foot soldiers (i.e. those that are randomly generated) may also receive [C-](/wiki/C-ration "C-ration") or [K-rations](/wiki/K-ration "K-ration"). The exact contents of each trooper's inventory is dependent on their experience and rank.

All mercenaries are eligible for a random [offensive item](/wiki/Offensive_item "Offensive item").

### Weapons

As lower-ranking mercenaries, soldiers and watchmen have a 1⁄3 chance of being generated with a random weapon from the set of all [polearms](/wiki/Polearm "Polearm"), plus [lances](/wiki/Lance "Lance") and [dwarvish mattocks](/wiki/Dwarvish_mattock "Dwarvish mattock") - if this is the case, they will always get either a knife or a [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger") as a secondary weapon, with equal probability.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Otherwise, their primary weapon will have be either an ordinary [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear") or an ordinary [short sword](/wiki/Short_sword "Short sword") with equal probability, and they will have a 3⁄4 chance of taking a knife as a secondary weapon.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Lances and mattocks no longer generate as starting weapons on watchmen and soldiers.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

Higher-ranked mercenaries randomly take one of two primary weapons with equal probability, and also have a 3⁄4 chance of taking a knife as a secondary weapon. Sergeants choose either a [flail](/wiki/Flail "Flail") or a [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace"); lieutenants choose either an ordinary [broadsword](/wiki/Broadsword "Broadsword") or a [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword"); and captains (including watch captains) choose either a long sword or a [silver saber](/wiki/Silver_saber "Silver saber").

### Armor

Each rank of soldier has a particular *target AC* as follows:

| Rank                | Target AC |
| ------------------- | --------- |
| soldier or watchman | 3         |
| sergeant            | 0         |
| guard               | −1        |
| lieutenant          | −2        |
| watch captain       | −2        |
| captain             | −3        |

The game uses a complicated procedure to outfit each mercenary with a selection of armor giving roughly the target AC. Depending on how the dice roll, a soldier might be given less armor or might be given enchanted armor that takes them beyond the target. Each mercenary is generated with one suit of body armor, and will always receive [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor") at bare minimum. All ranks are eligible for [ring mail](/wiki/Ring_mail "Ring mail") or [studded leather armor](/wiki/Studded_leather_armor "Studded leather armor"); sergeants and above, including guards, are eligible for [splint mail](/wiki/Splint_mail "Splint mail") or [banded mail](/wiki/Banded_mail "Banded mail"); and lieutenants and captains, including watch captains, are eligible for [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail") or [crystal plate mail](/wiki/Crystal_plate_mail "Crystal plate mail"). In addition, mercenaries of all ranks may be randomly generated with any of the items from the following list:

- [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet")
- [dented pot](/wiki/Dented_pot "Dented pot")
- [small shield](/wiki/Small_shield "Small shield")
- [large shield](/wiki/Large_shield "Large shield")
- [low boots](/wiki/Low_boots "Low boots")
- [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots")
- [leather gloves](/wiki/Leather_gloves "Leather gloves")
- [leather cloak](/wiki/Leather_cloak "Leather cloak")

There is no guarantee that any particular non-body armor slot will be filled, and they can be given multiple items for any slot.

### Other equipment

Yendorian army fighters that are randomly generated have a 1⁄3 chance of being generated with a K-ration, and an independent 1⁄2 chance of being generated with a C-ration; sergeants and above also have a 1⁄3 chance of being generated with a [bugle](/wiki/Bugle "Bugle").[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Unlike all other monster types, low-ranking mercenaries have only a 1⁄13 chance of being generated with random [defensive items](/wiki/Defensive_item "Defensive item"), [miscellaneous items](/wiki/Miscellaneous_item "Miscellaneous item"), and [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold");[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) other mercenaries have the same chance as normal.

## Bribery

All mercenaries can be [bribed](/wiki/Bribe "Bribe") by throwing [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold") at them, which will turn them [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") if successful. The amount of gold necessary for this is as follows:

![
x + \frac{G + 1d5 \times {\mathit XL}}{{\mathit Cha}}
](/images/math/f/1/d/f1d36b2e5f149e914dcf2c9bbda29e40.png)

![G](/images/math/d/f/c/dfcf28d0734569a6a693bc8194de62bf.png) is the total gold in your open inventory and ![x](/images/math/9/d/d/9dd4e461268c8034f5c8564e155c67a6.png) varies depending on the exact type of monster: 150 for soldiers, 250 for sergeants, 500 for lieutenants, and 750 for captains. Yendorian army soldiers only have a two in three chance of accepting the offer, while directly bribing the watch will always fail.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## Messages

- That should do. Now beat it!

  You successfully bribed a mercenary, turning them peaceful.

- That's not enough, coward!

  An attempt to bribe a mercenary failed.

## Variants

In some variants, some mercenaries are made into "[racial monsters](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster")", meaning that they can be of various creature types such as [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)"), [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_attribute\) "Orc (monster attribute)"), and [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)") - this is accompanied by changes to the inventory they are generated with, e.g. foregoing body armor for a [giant](/wiki/Giant_\(monster_attribute\) "Giant (monster attribute)") watchman. These mercenaries will still appear as @ to the player.

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), all mercenaries are eligible to be racial monsters.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), the Field Marshal's Baton grants [warning versus mercenaries](/wiki/Warned_of_monster_type "Warned of monster type").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), soldiers and the Watch can be of various races, including [drow](/wiki/Drow_\(monster_attribute\) "Drow (monster attribute)") and [centaurs](/index.php?title=Centaur_\(monster_attribute\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Centaur (monster attribute) (page does not exist)").

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [makemon.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 190](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/makemon.c#line190 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/makemon.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [fix github issue #623 - soldiers and mattocks](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/da859c5eb88e17d04ec2bb37e2c12842e9f4c4a9)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [makemon.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 549](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/makemon.c#line549 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/makemon.c")
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [makemon.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 653](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/makemon.c#line653 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/makemon.c")
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [dokick.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 299](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dokick.c#line299 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dokick.c")
